valueString:
RESULT: 


Indication: 


Neurofibromatosis


Technique:


1. MR images of the brain from outside institution dated 7/6/2009: 
Sagittal T1, axial DWI with ADC maps, axial GRE, axial FLAIR, axial T1, 
axial T2, and postcontrast axial and coronal T1-weighted images of the 
brain.
2. CT neck dated 7/7/2011: Axial CT images of the neck were obtained with 
intravenous contrast.
3. MRI images of the brain, cervical spine, thoracic spine, and lumbar 
spine dated 9/22/2011: Sagittal T1, axial DTI with calculated trace, FA, 
and color FA maps, axial T2 Star, axial FLAIR, axial T1, axial T2, and 
postcontrast axial, coronal, and sagittal T1-weighted images of the 
brain, as well as sagittal T2, T1, STIR, and postcontrast axial and 
sagittal T1-weighted images of the cervical, thoracic, and lumbar spine.


Comparison:
None.


Findings:
MRI brain 7/6/2009: There are few foci of nonspecific white matter T2 
hyperintensity. There is no evidence of acute infarct, intracranial 
hemorrhage, or extra-axial collection. Ventricles and sulci are 
age-appropriate. There is no mass effect or midline shift. Post contrast 
images demonstrate no abnormal enhancement within the brain or the 
meninges. Specifically, the cerebellopontine angle cisterns are normal in 
appearance as are the internal auditory canals. 


A multilobulated T2 hyperintense, enhancing lesion is seen within the 
left occipital scalp, measuring 1.5 x 3.9 x 2.8 cm in total conglomerate. 
There is also a multilobulated lesion with similar characteristics 
involving the left retromolar trigone, measuring 2.0 x 1.1 cm in maximum 
axial oblique dimensions, and approximately 1.7 cm in craniocaudal 
dimension.


Globes and orbits are normal in appearance. There is a retention cyst 
within the alveolar recess of the left maxillary sinus. Remainder of the 
paranasal sinuses are clear. The mastoid air cells are clear.


CT neck 7/7/2011: A multilobulated left occipital scalp lesion is again 
demonstrated, with portable lobules appearing to demonstrate a focal area 
of calcification. The left retromolar trigone lesion is also visualized 
however is less well demarcated compared to the prior MRI of the brain 
secondary to streak artifact. Visualized portions of the intracranial 
structures are unremarkable. There are multiple mildly centrally 
hypoattenuating lesions throughout the neck, extending from the 
neuroforamina outward. The largest lesion is seen in on the left, which 
extends from the C3-C4 neural foramen, and on coronal images measures 
approximately 5.9 x 2.2 cm in oblique dimensions. There is expansion of 
the neuroforamina. Smaller scattered scalp nodules are also seen.  
Additional mass lesions is seen associated with the intercostal nerves, 
the largest at the right lung apex which measures 2.7 x 4.3 cm between 
the second and third ribs.


Vessels of the neck demonstrate normal enhancement. The pharyngeal mucosa 
is normal in appearance. There is enlargement of the left laryngeal 
ventricle. A lesion is seen posterior to the left hypopharynx, indenting 
the piriform sinus. Submandibular and parotid glands are normal in 
appearance. The lung parenchyma is unremarkable. No osseous lesions are 
seen.


MRI brain and spine dated 9/22/2011: There is no evidence of acute 
infarct, intracranial hemorrhage, or extra-axial collection. Previously 
demonstrated tiny foci of white matter T2 hyperintensity are less well 
appreciated. There is no mass effect or midline shift. Postcontrast 
images demonstrate no abnormal enhancement within the brain or the 
meninges. Again noted are lobulated lesions within the left occipital 
scalp, as well as the left retromolar trigone, without change compared to 
the prior study. Extra-axial structures are likewise stable with 
persistent retention cyst within the left maxillary sinus.


And imaging the cervical spine demonstrates reversal of the usual 
cervical lordosis. Mild disc bulges are seen at C4-C5, C5-C6, and C6-C7 
however without significant spinal canal narrowing. There is no 
degenerative neuroforaminal narrowing. The spinal cord is normal in 
signal and morphology.


Again noted are multiple enhancing lesion extending from the 
neuroforamina bilaterally, the largest at the C3-4 level on the left, 
appearing to be without significant change compared to the CT neck of 
7/7/2011 allowing for intermodality differences.


Imaging of the thoracic spine is limited secondary to motion artifact. 
Multiple intercostal lesions are again seen, largest on the right between 
the second and third ribs. Otherwise soft tissue lesions appear to be 
less prominent compared to the cervical spine. A lesion is seen anterior 
to the T4 vertebral body. No significant degenerative changes are seen 
within the thoracic spine, and the thoracic cord is normal in signal and 
morphology.


No definite lesions are seen within the lumbar spine. There are minor 
degenerative changes within the lumbar spine, without high-grade spinal 
canal or neuroforaminal narrowing.
